message_1: Consider the sphere $S^2$ with two points $p$ and $q$ on it. Calculate the fundamental group $\pi_1(S^2-pq)$, which represents all the closed paths on $S^2$ starting at the point $p$ and ending at the point $q$, up to continuous deformation.
message_2:
The problem statement seems to have a small confusion. The fundamental group is defined for a topological space, not for a pair of points. So, we should be looking for the fundamental group of $S^2$ with two points removed, say $p$ and $q$. Let's denote this punctured sphere by $X = S^2 - \{p, q\}$.

Now, we will compute the fundamental group $\pi_1(X)$.

Consider a stereographic projection from the point $p$ onto a plane. Under this projection, the sphere $S^2$ minus the point $p$ is homeomorphic to the plane $\mathbb{R}^2$. The point $q$ will be projected to some point $q'$ in the plane. So, we have a homeomorphism $f: X \to \mathbb{R}^2 - \{q'\}$.

Now, let's compute the fundamental group of $\mathbb{R}^2 - \{q'\}$. We can use the deformation retraction of $\mathbb{R}^2 - \{q'\}$ onto a circle $S^1$ centered at $q'$ with some radius. This deformation retraction gives us a homotopy equivalence between $\mathbb{R}^2 - \{q'\}$ and $S^1$. Since the fundamental group is a homotopy invariant, we have $\pi_1(\mathbb{R}^2 - \{q'\}) \cong \pi_1(S^1)$.

The fundamental group of the circle $S^1$ is well-known to be isomorphic to the integers, i.e., $\pi_1(S^1) \cong \mathbb{Z}$.

Now, since $f: X \to \mathbb{R}^2 - \{q'\}$ is a homeomorphism, it induces an isomorphism between the fundamental groups of $X$ and $\mathbb{R}^2 - \{q'\}$. Therefore, we have $\pi_1(X) \cong \pi_1(\mathbb{R}^2 - \{q'\}) \cong \pi_1(S^1) \cong \mathbb{Z}$.

So, the fundamental group of the punctured sphere $S^2 - \{p, q\}$ is isomorphic to the integers, i.e., $\pi_1(S^2 - \{p, q\}) \cong \mathbb{Z}$.
